titleInfo.title: LSU History Oral History Project: Women at LSU
titleInfo.subTitle: Jo Stumberg oral history interview, 1978

name.description: Jo Stumberg was born in Baton Rouge, Louisiana on October 5, 1902. She received her undergraduate degree in 1922, a Master of Education degree in 1928, and a Master of Science degree in 1937, all from Louisiana State University. She is the daughter of Charles Stumberg, Professor of German at LSU from 1895-1938.

subject.topic: Louisiana State University and Agricultural and Mechanical College--Alumni and alumnae.
Louisiana State University and Agricultural and Mechanical College--Faculty.
Louisiana State University and Agricultural and Mechanical College--History.

mods.note: Louisiana State University Libraries Special Collections (http://www.lib.lsu.edu/special)
mods.accessCondition: Physical rights are retained by the LSU Libraries. Copyright is retained by the interviewee and her heirs and Louisiana State University in accordance with U.S. copyright laws.

"E-mail lsudiglib@lsu.edu with questions or comments. See instructions for ordering reprints of this audio here: http://www.lib.lsu.edu/special/services/duplication.html Mention the ""Item number"" or ""Item URL"" in your request. "
mods.abstract: "Interview discusses Stumberg's first Master's thesis on occupations for women in Baton Rouge; her parents' unique opinions for the time; and campus life on the old campus. Mentions her career as an elementary school teacher and then, LSU teacher in the 1930s; first to teach home economics; and overseeing the ""tin shop"". Also mentions being fired by Huey Long; the lives and status of women during the 1920-1930s; and the expansion of LSU."
